SENT.plain: The purpose of this study was to test our hypothesis that red palm oil (RPO) intake may affect abnormalities of myocardial connexin-43 (Cx43) and protein kinase Cε (PKCε) signaling, and consequently the propensity of the spontaneously hypertensive rat heart (SHR) heart to arrhythmias
SHR and Wistar-Kyoto (WKY) rats fed a standard rat chow plus red palm oil (200 µL/day) for 5 weeks were compared with untreated rats

Cytosolic but not particulate PKCε expression as well as Cx43-mRNA, total Cx43 proteins, and its phoshorylated forms were increased, and disordered localization of Cx43 was attenuated in the left ventricle of RPO-fed SHR compared with untreated rats
These alterations were associated with suppression of early post-ischemic-reperfusion-related ventricular tachycardia and electrically inducible ventricular fibrillation
However, the treatment dose of RPO caused down-regulation of myocardial Cx43, but did not alter its cell membrane distribution or overall PKCε expression in WKY rats
It was, however, associated with poor arrhythmia protection, suggesting overdosing
Results indicate that SHR benefit from RPO intake, particularly because of its apparent anti-arrhythmic effects
This protection can be, in part, attributed to the preservation of cell-to-cell communication via up-regulation of myocardial Cx43, but not with PKCε activation
